awd_titl_txt: Quantum Simulation of Out-of-Equilibrium Spin Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Simulating complex systems on a computer improves our understanding of natural phenomena and helps to develope new technology. Yet, some systems are beyond the simulation capabilities of even the most advanced supercomputers. Quantum simulators could overcome this challenge and greatly impact quantum chemistry, material science, condensed matter, and high-energy physics. While general-purpose quantum computers promise to more broadly revolutionize computing, they are still in their infancy, while quantum simulators can already tackle some task-specific problems. This is achieved by following a different approach than computer-based simulators, by using one quantum system to directly mimic the evolution of another, target system. The weakness in this strategy is that it lacks flexibility. 
This project aims to expand the capabilities of quantum simulation by introducing programmable analog quantum simulators which combine the ease of directly mimicking a system evolution, with the flexibility of engineering the simulator dynamics via logic gates. In addition, the project will develop novel metrics to evaluate performance and to acquire the most comprehensive information about the simulated system.

To achieve these goals, the researchers will employ a hybrid approach, combining evolution under the natural Hamiltonian (as in analog quantum simulators) with periodic control (collective quantum gates) to engineer a Floquet Hamiltonian approximating the interaction models of interest. As the simulation performance should be assessed on large (scalable) quantum systems not accessible to classical simulators, the project will validate the quantum control protocols experimentally, devising experimentally accessible metrics that can characterize the many-body dynamics, such as out-of-time ordered correlations and Loschmidt echoes. The systems used as quantum simulators will include quasi-1D nuclear spin chains, nuclear spins in 3D crystals, and spin impurities in diamond. There are several advantages of using spin systems to address these questions over synthetic matter systems such as cold atoms and ions. First, the system directly maps to typical spin Hamiltonians studied theoretically and it can build upon the long tradition of magnetic resonance investigation of condensed matter physics. In addition, these spin systems allow exploring broader regimes than cold atoms and ions, for example high-temperature conditions, and conditions that are well beyond what can be simulated exactly, such as large, 3D systems, and open systems interacting with a well-defined environment. Exploring the out-of-equilibrium dynamics of such rich spin systems will bring forward a host of new physical phenomena, as it will be demonstrated with a few paradigmatic examples of quantum spin models. A particular focus of the project is on investigating quantum thermalization or its absence due to localization or prethermalization, a key question in the quest to exploit many-body systems for quantum applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
"Analog quantum simulators could offer significant potential in various scientific and technological domains. These simulators leverage the principles of quantum mechanics to model and study complex systems, which are otherwise intractable for classical computers. Complementing analog simulators with programmability would significantly further expand the realm of their applications, including solving complex problems in quantum chemistry, materials science, and high-energy physics, where understanding quantum phenomena is crucial.

The power of programmable analog quantum simulators stems from their ability to mimic the behavior of other quantum systems accurately. This capability allows for exploring quantum states and dynamics that are otherwise beyond reach, thus providing deeper insights into quantum mechanics and enabling the discovery of new materials and drugs.

However, this same complex dynamics poses several challenges to the practical realization of these simulators. The complexity of quantum systems requires precise control at the quantum level, which is a non-trivial task. Additionally, interpreting the results obtained from quantum simulators can be challenging, as it requires measuring complex observables such as long-range correlations and entanglement.

This project’s goal was to make quantum simulators more controllable, their results more measurable, making their processes easier to observe and understand. The advances were tested experimentally in large quantum spin systems using magnetic resonance techniques. We focused on three main aspects:

  1. Creating Control Schemes: We developed ways to better control the quantum simulators. This involves finding methods to shape the Hamiltonian (the basic interaction) that guides the system's evolution and thus the simulation. We used both numerical methods (such as reinforcement learning) and geometric analytical methods to achieve high-fidelity in controlling strongly interacting quantum systems. We further devised ways to measure the control accuracy using methods that are practical and can be done in experiments, avoiding overly complex measurement techniques such as quantum process tomography, which is difficult to implement.

  2. Developing Powerful Metrics and Observables: Observables are critical tools to characterize the results of the quantum simulation. Typically, this involves non-local correlations (even quantum in nature, such as entanglement) that cannot be directly measured using practical experimental apparatuses. The team developed new and effective observables to track the evolution of the simulations. These included techniques like out-of-time ordered correlations, Loschmidt echoes, and two-time correlators. We further achieved the first measurement of a strongly interacting system at the single spin level, relying only on the existence of local disorder, even when the measurement cannot achieve the required spatial resolution. The technique effectively achieved sub-nanometer spatial resolution.

  3. Exploring Paradigmatic Open Problems in Quantum Many-Body Evolution: We applied our control methods and metrics to analyze paradigmatic many-body evolutions, such as emergent hydrodynamics behavior, the robustness of prethermal states, as well as to realize novel forms of matter, such as the creation of a time crystal. These applications immediately showcased the potential of the novel tools we introduced.

In addition to providing opportunities for training in quantum information science and engineering, this project advanced this broader discipline by providing novel tools and results that can be applied broadly to many other experimental platforms.
